questions.question: A 35 y/o male presents with exertional dyspnea and palpitations during sports activities. His family history is significant for a relative who experienced sudden cardiac death at a young age. In managing this patient with suspected hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM), which of the following is a first-line treatment option to relieve symptoms?
questions.explanation: β -Adrenergic blocking agent is the first-line treatment for conditions such as hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM), effectively reducing heart rate and improving diastolic filling, thereby alleviating symptoms like exertional dyspnea and palpitations. Treatment of HOCM Medical Management First-line Medications: β -Adrenergic Blocking Agents (e.g., Metaprolol): Reduce heart rate and improve diastolic filling. L-type Calcium Channel Blockers (e.g., Verapamil): Help decrease contractility and relieve outflow obstruction. Additional Therapy for Persistent Symptoms: Disopyramide: An antiarrhythmic agent with negative inotropic properties to control exertional dyspnea and chest pain. Surgical and Procedural Options Surgical Myectomy: Effective in relieving outflow tract obstruction by excising part of the septal myocardium. Alcohol Septal Ablation: Suitable for patients with appropriate coronary anatomy; involves controlled infarction to relieve obstruction. Primarily for patients who prefer to avoid surgery or have comorbidities. Risk Stratification and Management for Sudden Cardiac Death (SCD) in Hypertrophic Obstructive Cardiomyopathy (HOCM) Increased Risk for SCD: HOCM patients are at heightened risk for sudden cardiac death, primarily from ventricular tachyarrhythmias. Physical Activity Guidelines: Traditional prohibitions against vigorous exercise are under reconsideration in ongoing studies. Implantable Cardioverter-Defibrillator (ICD) Recommendations: Indications Recommended for patients with two or more risk factors for SCD. Considered selectively for those with one risk factor. Strongly indicated for patients who have previously survived cardiac arrest due to ventricular fibrillation or sustained ventricular tachycardia. High-Risk Features for Primary Prevention Unexplained syncope Abnormal blood pressure response during exercise Significant ventricular hypertrophy (>30mm thickness) Family history of SCD Multiple episodes of non-sustained ventricular tachycardia (NSVT) Enalapril (Option A) and Candesartan (Option C) which are ACE inhibitors and Angiotensin receptor Blockers respectively are contraindicated in the management of HOCM. Surgical Myomectomy (Option D) is a surgical intervention reserved for patients with severe symptoms who do not respond to medical management, not a first-line treatment.

questions.question: A 55 y/o woman presents with acute chest pain, difficulty breathing, and signs of heart failure following sudden emotional distress. Her ECG shows ST-segment elevation without reciprocal depression, and echocardiography reveals ballooning of the left ventricular apex. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: of ST-segment elevation without reciprocal depression, and "takotsubo" ballooning on echocardiography, points to Takotsubo cardiomyopathy, also known as stress cardiomyopathy. This condition is often triggered by emotional or physical stress, mimicking acute coronary syndrome without coronary artery obstruction. Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy (Broken Heart syndrome) Yamaguchi Syndrome (Apical Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy) Definition: Takotsubo cardiomyopathy, or stress cardiomyopathy, is a transient condition characterized by left ventricular apical ballooning often triggered by emotional or physical stress, mimicking acute coronary syndrome without coronary obstruction. Epidemiology : Predominantly affects postmenopausal women, triggered by emotional or physical stress. Clinical Presentation : Chest pain, signs of acute heart failure, resembling acute coronary syndrome. ECG : ST-segment elevation, absent reciprocal depression, T-wave inversion, mild QT prolongation. Biochemistry : Elevated catecholamines, BNP, and modest troponin rise. Imaging : Echocardiography : Classic "takotsubo" ballooning of the left ventricular apex, with basal segments hyperdynamic and apex hypokinetic. Can show left ventricular outflow tract obstruction or mitral regurgitation. MRI : Apical ballooning with high T2 intensity (oedema), typically sparing the basal segments. No late enhancement, differentiating it from anterior STEMI. Left Ventriculography : Demonstrates transient dysfunction and ballooning of mid and apical segments of the left ventricle. Prognosis : Excellent recovery with supportive treatment, typically resolves in weeks to months. Definition : A rare form of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy affecting the left ventricle's apex, occasionally the right or both. Epidemiology : More common in Japanese populations (15-25% of HCM cases) compared to the U.S. (~3%). Symptoms : Often asymptomatic; possible symptoms include chest pain, palpitations, dyspnea, and syncope. ECG Findings : Left ventricular hypertrophy with deep negative T waves, especially in leads V4-V5. Pathology : Usually sporadic, with occasional autosomal dominant inheritance. Imaging : "Ace-of-spades" or "spade-like" left ventricle configuration on imaging configuration on ventriculogram" data-author="A. PayusFarisha SholehN. Mustafa" data-hash="8753" data-license="Open access" data-source="https://www.semanticscholar.org/paper/Yamaguchi-syndrome-%E2%80%93-A-pseudoacute-corona ry-of-the-Payus-Sholeh/6aff765d73025529152e4756f377ead16487bb54/figure/3" data-tags="April2025" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/BknugIRWXDkiz5PAHEME1744301744.png" /> Myocardial infarction (Option A) typically presents with ST-segment elevation and reciprocal depression, which is absent here. Aortic dissection (Option C) would present with severe chest pain radiating to the back and may not cause ST-segment elevation. Yamaguchi syndrome (Option D) (apical hypertrophic cardiomyopathy) involves hypertrophy and apical thickening but does not present with acute chest pain or ST-segment elevation.

questions.question: A 55-year-old patient presents with sharp chest pain, fever, and pleuritis 3 weeks after undergoing coronary artery bypass surgery. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism?
questions.explanation: autoimmune response to antigens from the injured myocardium following surgery. Post-cardiac injury syndrome Definition : Postcardiac Injury Syndrome is acute pericarditis triggered by prior injury to the heart, leading to blood in the pericardial cavity. Causes : Can follow cardiac surgery, trauma, catheterization, or occasionally a myocardial infarction. Symptoms : Sharp chest pain (mimicking viral/idiopathic pericarditis), fever, pleuritis, and pneumonitis, typically appearing 1–4 weeks after injury. Recurrences can happen over several years. Pathophysiology : Likely due to an autoimmune reaction against myocardial/pericardial antigens. Treatment : Usually self-limiting; managed with aspirin or NSAIDs. Severe or recurring cases may require colchicine or glucocorticoids. Bacterial pericarditis (Option A) : Unlikely, as it typically presents sooner after surgery and with signs of sepsis. Direct trauma from the procedure (Option C) : Less likely, as trauma-related pain would generally occur immediately post-surgery, not weeks later. Viral infection (Option D) : Unlikely, as viral pericarditis is not typically related to recent cardiac surgery or triggered by myocardial antigens. Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 2023

questions.question: A post-mortem study reveals fibrinous deposits between the pericardial leaflets with a “bread and butter” appearance. Which of the following is most consistent with this form of pericarditis?
questions.explanation: leukocytic exudate on the pericardium. Bread and butter appearance seen in fibrinous pericarditis Types of Pericarditis Fibrinous pericarditis Often called "bread and butter" pericarditis due to fibrin deposits creating a rough appearance on the pericardium. Caused by conditions like myocardial infarction, infections, trauma, or systemic diseases. Associated with a granular, opaque pericardial surface from fibrin and leukocytic exudate. Serous pericarditis Characterized by clear fluid accumulation, often seen in viral infections or autoimmune diseases. Less intense inflammation than fibrinous type. Purulent pericarditis (Option B ruled out) Caused by bacterial infections, leading to a pus-filled pericardial sac. Requires urgent treatment to prevent severe complications. Haemorrhagic pericarditis (Option A ruled out) Involves blood within the pericardium, often due to trauma, malignancy, or uremia. Common in cases with malignancies like lung or breast cancer. Caseous pericarditis (Option D ruled out) Rare and typically associated with tuberculosis. Has a cheese-like appearance due to necrotic tissue in the pericardium.

questions.question: A 55 y/o male presents to the emergency department with fatigue, shortness of breath, and swollen legs. Upon examination, his heart on imaging revealed the following, and his left ventricular ejection fraction is markedly reduced. Which of the following is NOT a recognised cause of this patient’s diagnosis?
questions.explanation: imaging showing an enlarged heart and a markedly reduced left ventricular ejection fraction, indicative of dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM). Scleroderma is primarily a connective tissue disease and is not directly recognized as a cause of dilated cardiomyopathy but is linked to Restrictive cardiomyopathy. Dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM) is characterised by an enlarged left ventricle and reduced systolic function, as evidenced by a decreased left ventricular ejection fraction. It predominantly features systolic failure, while diastolic dysfunction is less prominent. DCM can result from various etiologies, leading to common pathways of secondary response and disease progression. Causes of Dilated Cardiomyopathy Infective Viral ( coxsackievirus , adenovirus, HIV, hepatitis C) Parasitic ( Chagas’ disease , trypanosomiasis, toxoplasmosis) (Option B ruled out) Bacterial ( diphtheria ) Spirochetal ( Lyme disease) Rickettsial (Q fever) Fungal (with systemic infection) Noninfective Granulomatous inflammatory disease Sarcoidosis (Option A ruled out) Giant cell myocarditis Eosinophilic myocarditis Polymyositis, dermatomyositis Collagen vascular disease Checkpoint inhibitor chemotherapy Transplant rejection Toxic Alcohol Catecholamines (amphetamines, cocaine) Chemotherapeutic agents (anthracyclines, trastuzumab ) Interferon Other therapeutic agents ( hydroxychloroquine , chloroquine) Drugs of misuse (emetine, anabolic steroids) Heavy metals ( lead, mercury ) (Option D ruled out) Occupational exposure (hydrocarbons, arsenicals) Metabolic Nutritional deficiencies ( thiamine, selenium , carnitine) Electrolyte deficiencies (calcium, phosphate, magnesium) Endocrinopathy (thyroid disease, pheochromocytoma, diabetes,

questions.question: A 55-year-old male is being evaluated for restrictive cardiomyopathy (RCM). Which of the following statements regarding the investigations and treatment options for RCM is FALSE?

options.A: An echocardiogram is the primary test for diagnosing RCM.
options.B: Low-to-normal QRS voltage on ECG can suggest amyloidosis.
options.C: Therapeutic phlebotomy is the primary treatment for sarcoidosis.
options.D: Endomyocardial biopsy is the gold standard for diagnosing cardiac amyloidosis.

questions.explanation: absence of low voltage does not rule it out. (Option B ruled out) Echocardiogram: It is the primary test for RCM and helps differentiate it from conditions like constrictive pericarditis. (Option A ruled out) Thickened walls of both ventricles without major chamber dilation. The atria are markedly dilated, indicating chronically elevated ventricular filling pressures. There is a characteristic hyperrefractile “glittering” appearance of the myocardium, typical of amyloid infiltration. Granular sparkling heart Cardiac Magnetic Resonance (CMR): Useful for diagnosing RCM and suggests amyloidosis through gadolinium enhancement. Endomyocardial Biopsy (EMB): Gold standard for diagnosing cardiac amyloidosis; fat pad aspiration is also beneficial. (Option D ruled out) Nuclear Imaging: Can show affinity for amyloid and aid in diagnosis. Biomarkers: Troponin T, BNP, and pro-BNP are useful for diagnosis and prognosis. Mutation Analysis: Used to diagnose hereditary hemochromatosis. Treat Underlying Causes: Focus on alleviating symptoms and managing heart failure. Diuretics: Mainstay for reducing volume overload; must be monitored to avoid excessive diuresis. Beta-blockers/Calcium Channel Blockers: May be used to increase filling time and manage dysrhythmias. Angiotensin-Receptor Blockers: Considered if systolic heart failure develops. For Sarcoidosis: Antiarrhythmics and immunosuppressive agents like corticosteroids may be used. For Hemochromatosis: Therapeutic phlebotomy is the treatment of choice. An echocardiogram shows normal systolic function but diastolic dysfunction. The chest X-ray of the patient is given below. Which of the following statements is true?

questions.explanation: like amyloidosis. The patient's symptoms—shortness of breath, fatigue, leg swelling, jugular venous distension, and ascites—are indicative of heart failure due to restricted ventricular filling. Chest X-ray shows right heart margin enlargement, likely due to left atrial dilation causing an overlap sign. The echocardiogram findings further support this diagnosis, showing normal systolic function with evidence of diastolic dysfunction. In patients with RCM, particularly those with amyloidosis, you can also observe specific signs like rapid Y descents in jugular venous pressure, which is consistent with the heart's impaired ability to fill. questions.question: A 45-year-old man presents with worsening fatigue, shortness of breath, and ankle swelling. His medical history includes joint pain, elevated liver enzymes, hyperpigmentation, and diabetes. He has recently been diagnosed with a metabolic disorder. An echocardiogram reveals elevated filling pressures and bilateral atrial enlargement. Which of the following best explains the underlying pathophysiology of this patient’s condition?

options.A: Increased contractility due to myocardial hypertrophy
options.B: Impaired diastolic filling due to stiffened ventricular walls
options.C: Dilated ventricular chambers leading to heart failure
options.D: Obstruction of blood flow through the left ventricle

questions.explanation: condition such as hemochromatosis that leads to ventricular wall stiffness. The stiffened ventricular walls impede proper filling during diastole, leading to increased end-diastolic pressures and symptoms of heart failure, such as fatigue and peripheral oedema. Restrictive Cardiomyopathy Characterized by abnormal diastolic function, often with mildly reduced contractility and ejection fraction (usually 30–50%). Causes Infiltrative diseases : Amyloidosis (Most common cause) Sarcoidosis Hemochromatosis Fibrotic conditions : Radiation therapy Scleroderma Endomyocardial fibrosis Storage diseases : Glycogen storage diseases (types II, III) Fabry's disease Pathophysiology Abnormal Diastolic Function The primary abnormality in restrictive cardiomyopathy is impaired diastolic filling due to the stiffened ventricular walls. Elevated end-diastolic pressures in both ventricles without significant chamber dilation. Bilateral Atrial Enlargement The non-compliant ventricles lead to increased pressures, resulting in dilation of both atria. Right-Sided Heart Failure The stiff ventricles result in increased filling pressures, particularly affecting the right side, causing peripheral oedema, ascites, and jugular venous distention. Amyloid Infiltration (in amyloidosis) Amyloid fibrils (pink hyaline deposits) accumulate between myocytes, leading to myocardial stiffening and restrictive physiology. amyloidosis in congo red stain" data-author="Novikov, Aleksey & Holzer, Horatio & DeSimone, Robert & Abu-Zeinah, Ghaith & Pisapia, David & Mark, Tomer & Pastore, Raymond." data-hash="8672" data-license="CC0" data-source="https://www.research gate.net/figure/Cardiac-amyloidosis-A-Congo-red-stain-of-left-ventricle-showing-focal-positive_fig1_284096165 " data-tags="April2025" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/dJpPe8RwpqgEgabbGhLT1744298841.png" /> Cardiac amyloidosis (Congo red stain) Fibrosis In conditions like radiation-induced cardiomyopathy or endomyocardial fibrosis, stiffening of the myocardium occurs due to scarring, further impairing ventricular filling. Increased contractility due to myocardial hypertrophy (Option A) is incorrect because restrictive cardiomyopathy typically exhibits preserved or mildly reduced contractility, not increased contractility. Dilated ventricular chambers leading to heart failure (Option C) do not apply, as dilated ventricular chambers are not characteristic of restrictive cardiomyopathy. Obstruction of blood flow through the left ventricle (Option D) is also incorrect, as obstruction of blood flow is more commonly associated with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy rather than restrictive cardiomyopathy.

questions.question: A 30-year-old female marathon runner collapses and is found unresponsive during a race. Despite attempts at resuscitation, she is pronounced dead at the scene. Her family reports a history of sudden cardiac death in her brother at a young age, and they mention that she had previously experienced episodes of dizziness and palpitations during training. Which of the following conditions is most likely to contribute to sudden cardiac death in this young athlete?
questions.explanation: athletes, especially in those with a family history of sudden death, like this patient. The symptoms of dizziness and palpitations during training strongly suggest HCM. Sudden Cardiac Death (SCD) Sudden Cardiac Death (SCD) is defined as unexpected death occurring within an hour of symptom onset due to cardiac causes, including unwitnessed deaths in individuals who seemed healthy within the last 24 hours. Risk Factors Structural Heart Disease: The presence of structural heart issues or inherited arrhythmia syndromes significantly increases SCD risk. Major Risk Factors: Coronary Heart Disease (CHD) Heart Failure Diabetes Hypertension Smoking Family History of SCD Precipitating Factors SCD and Sudden Cardiac Arrest (SCA) frequently occur at specific times (e.g., mornings, winter months) and in public places. Vigorous exertion, especially in men, can trigger SCD; however, regular exercise may reduce this risk. Underlying Heart Disease The most common cause of SCD is Ventricular fibrillation Many SCD cases are linked to coronary artery disease (CAD), but non-ischemic cardiomyopathies and other heart conditions also contribute. Common mechanisms leading to SCD include: Acute Myocardial Infarction Bradyarrhythmias Ventricular scars leading to arrhythmias Commotio Cordis Commotio cordis is a specific cause of SCD, often resulting from an impact to the left chest by a hard object, such as a baseball, during sports. This can induce ventricular fibrillation and cardiac arrest in an otherwise structurally normal heart. (Option B ruled out) SCD in Athletes Younger Athletes: The leading causes of SCD are inherited cardiac conditions, particularly Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (HCM). Older Athletes: Risks are primarily associated with atherosclerotic coronary artery disease (CAD). Arrhythmogenic Right Ventricular Cardiomyopathy (ARVC): ARVC is recognised as a cause of ventricular tachycardia and SCD in young athletes, characterized by: Progressive fibrofatty replacement of the right ventricle Familial transmission Symptomatic arrhythmias Young athletes with ARVC may exhibit symptoms such as palpitations, dizziness, and unexplained syncope. Valvular heart disease (Option C) and Atherosclerotic coronary artery disease (Option D) are less likely to be the cause in a young, fit athlete. Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 2257,2259 www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/ NBK526014/#:~:text=Commotio%20cordis%20most%20commonly%20results,rupture%20or%20penetrating%20c hest%20injuries. www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4969030/ www.ccjm.org/content/ccjom/68/5/459.full.pdf www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/sudden-cardiac-arrest/symptoms-causes/syc-20350634

questions.question: Which of the following medications is not contraindicated in patients with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy?
questions.explanation: symptoms in patients with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. It helps decrease contractility and relieve outflow obstruction. In HOCM , the left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction worsens when the heart is under-filled (low preload) or when the heart has to contract more forcefully. Low preload results in reduced end-diastolic volume, exacerbating outflow obstruction due to a narrower channel. Increased contractility raises blood flow across the outflow tract, causing greater anterior displacement of the mitral leaflet, further obstructing the LVOT. This is why certain drugs are contraindicated in HOCM, as they can exacerbate the obstruction. Drugs contraindicated in Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Nitroglycerin: It causes vasodilation , which reduces preload. Furosemide: It causes diuresis, which leads to a reduction in blood volume hence a decrease in preload. (Option C ruled out) Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors : ACE inhibitors reduce afterload (the resistance the heart must pump against) and can also reduce preload by causing vasodilation and decreasing blood volume. Angiotensin receptor blockers: ARBs work similarly to ACE inhibitors by reducing afterload and preload . Digoxin : It works by increasing the contractility of the heart (Option D ruled out) Amlodipine : It is a calcium channel blocker causing peripheral vasodilation, hence causing decreased preload. (Option A ruled out) Reference: www.cardiosmart.org/patient-story/2020/11/every-patient-with-hypertrophic-cardiomyopathy-deserves- personalized-care-gl-hcm#:~:text=Nitroglycerine%20is%20dangerous%20in%20HCM%20because%20it,even%20 pass%20out%20if%20they%20take%20nitroglycerin. www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4807719/ www.scien cedirect.com/topics/agricultural-and-biological-sciences/furosemide#:~:text=It%20is%20used%20in%20the%20m anagement%20of,impossible%20(e.g.%2C%20in%20cases%20of%20hypertrophic%20cardiomyopathy).

questions.question: A 30 y/o male presents with exertional chest pain and occasional fainting spells. His family history includes a relative who experienced sudden cardiac death. An echocardiogram reveals asymmetric septal hypertrophy. Which of the following is not a characteristic investigatory finding in this condition?

options.B: Deep, narrow Q waves in the lateral leads
options.C: Left ventricle free wall thickness >10 mm

questions.explanation: exertional syncope and family history of sudden cardiac death, alongside echocardiographic findings of asymmetric septal hypertrophy, which are characteristic of HOCM. However, left ventricle free wall thickness >10 mm is incorrect as HOCM is characterized by left ventricle thickness >15 mm (typically >30 mm in severe cases). Investigations for HOCM Trans-Thoracic Echocardiography (T.T.E) Left ventricle free wall thickness >15 mm (> 30 mm, higher risk of sudden cardiac death) Systolic anterior movement of the mitral valve Asymmetrical septal hypertrophy ECG features of HOCM Left ventricular hypertrophy ( Sokolow-Lyon criteria : S wave depth in V1 + tallest R wave height in V5 or V6 > 35 mm) with increased precordial voltages and non-specific ST segment and T-wave abnormalities (Option D ruled out) Deep, narrow (“dagger-like”) Q waves in lateral (I, aVL, V5-6) +/- inferior (II, III, aVF) leads ( Option B ruled out) due to septal hypertrophy. lateral and inferior leads in HOCM" data-author="" data-hash="8660" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="April2025" height="437" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/9fQQmuLT8HXigM30f8Vf1744298138.png" width="437" /> Cardiac catheterization: In HOCM, left ventricular (LV) outflow obstruction due to thickened septal muscle creates a systolic pressure gradient between the LV and the aortic valve, illustrated by the Brockenbrough–Braunwald–Morrow sign , which occurs when a premature ventricular contraction leads to a decrease in aortic pressure and an increase in LV pressure during the subsequent contraction. (Option A ruled out) Square root sign : Seen in constrictive pericarditis and restrictive cardiomyopathy. Early diastolic filling : At the beginning of diastole, the ventricles fill quickly because there's no obstruction initially. This is the "dip" in the pattern. Late diastolic filling : However, as the ventricles continue to fill, they reach a limit quickly because the stiff pericardium restricts any further expansion. This leads to an abrupt stop in filling, causing the pressure to level off, which creates the "plateau" or flat line in the pattern.

questions.question: A 15-year-old male presents to the ED after experiencing syncope while playing basketball. He has a palpable double impulse at the apex, and an ECG shows signs of left ventricular hypertrophy. An echocardiogram reveals asymmetric septal thickening with left ventricular outflow tract obstruction. Which of the following examination findings would NOT be expected in this patient?

options.A: Palpable double impulse at the apex
options.B: Late-peaking ejection systolic murmur best heard at the left sternal border
options.C: Pulsus bisferiens on peripheral pulse examination
options.D: Prominent y descent in jugular venous pressure (JVP)

questions.explanation: septal thickening with outflow tract obstruction strongly suggest hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) , specifically hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM) . Prominent y descent in jugular venous pressure (JVP) is more typical of constrictive pericarditis rather than HOCM. Examination Findings : Clinical Finding Description Palpable Left Ventricular Hypertrophy An enlarged left ventricle can be felt during physical examination, indicating hypertrophy. Double Impulse at the Apex A palpable fourth heart sound suggests forceful atrial contraction against a non-compliant ventricle. (Option A ruled out) Mid-Systolic Murmur at the Base Turbulent blood flow through the obstructed left ventricular outflow tract produces a mid-systolic murmur. Pansystolic Murmur at the Apex Indicates mitral regurgitation caused by abnormal systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve. Jerky Arterial Pulse Characteristic of HOCM, contrasts with the slow-rising pulse seen in aortic stenosis. Pulsus bisferiens (Option C ruled out) A double pulse noticed during systole in the peripheral pulse is called pulsus bisferiens. It is associated with severe aortic disease accompanied by aortic regurgitation and HOCM. JVP in HCOM: Prominent "a" wave due to increased atrial pressure as the right atrium contracts against a stiff ventricle. May have elevated JVP Auscultatory Findings in Hypertrophic Obstructive Cardiomyopathy (HOCM): Auscultatory Feature Description Clinical Relevance Ejection Systolic Murmur (Option B ruled out) Late-onset crescendo-decrescendo murmur. Caused by turbulent blood flow through the obstructed LVOT; best heard at the left sternal border or apex. Dynamic Changes with Maneuvers Increased Intensity: Occurs with decreased preload (e.g., Valsalva manoeuvre, amyl nitrite). Indicates worsening obstruction. Decreased Intensity: Occurs with increased afterload (e.g., handgrip, inspiration). Suggests improvement in outflow tract obstruction. Non-Ejection Systolic Clicks Clicks due to asymmetrical hypertrophy affecting the mitral chordae tendinae. Indicates dynamic changes in the mitral apparatus, though less common. Abnormal Second Heart Sound (S2) May show delayed aortic closure with patterns of reverse splitting. Correlates with the severity of left ventricular outflow obstruction; reversed or partially reversed splitting indicates severe obstruction.

questions.question: A 30-year-old competitive athlete presents with recurrent syncope and exertional chest pain. He has a jerky, forceful pulse. ECG reveals left ventricular hypertrophy with deep Q waves in the inferolateral leads, and troponin T is mildly elevated. Echocardiography shows asymmetric septal hypertrophy, systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve, and a mid-systolic murmur at the heart's base. What is the most likely mechanism for his symptoms?

options.A: Diastolic heart failure due to a dilated left ventricle

questions.explanation: strongly suggest hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM) The mid-systolic murmur indicates obstruction to blood flow from the left ventricle during systole, which aligns with the presentation of HOCM . Left ventricular outflow tract obstruction is the hallmark of HOCM caused by asymmetric septal hypertrophy leading to dynamic obstruction during systole, which explains his effort-related symptoms and murmur. Hypertrophic Obstructive Cardiomyopathy (HOCM) Pathophysiology: Autosomal dominant disorder (a genetic disorder). Mutations : Beta-myosin heavy-chain : Leads to significant ventricular hypertrophy. Troponin : Minimal hypertrophy but associated with myocardial fibre disarray and sudden death. Myosin-binding protein C : Often presents later in life; linked to hypertension and arrhythmias. Key Characteristics : Inappropriate, extensive left ventricular hypertrophy. Misaligned myocardial fibres (helter skelter disarray) and myocardial fibrosis. A rigid left ventricle impedes diastolic filling, leading to heart failure. Dynamic left ventricular outflow tract obstruction (LVOTO) due to septal hypertrophy. Mitral regurgitation due to systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve. Clinical Features: Effort-Related Symptoms : Angina : Due to increased myocardial oxygen demand during exertion. Dyspnoea : Resulting from impaired diastolic filling and inefficient LV function. Syncope : Caused by reduced cardiac output during exertion. Sudden Death : The most common cause of sudden death in HOCM is ventricular fibrillation.High risk during intense physical activity, especially in young athletes. Distinct Pulse Characteristics : Jerky arterial pulse, distinguishing it from aortic stenosis . Diastolic heart failure due to a dilated left ventricle (Option A) : HOCM involves hypertrophy, not dilation, of the left ventricle. Mitral valve prolapse (Option B) : Not characteristic of HOCM ; instead, the systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve may lead to mitral regurgitation . Aortic stenosis (Option D) : While both conditions present a murmur, the arterial pulse in HOCM is typically jerky , unlike the slow-rising pulse in aortic stenosis.

questions.question: A 60-year-old male presents with signs of peripheral oedema and ascites. A chest X-ray reveals the following, and echocardiography confirms a thickened pericardium. Which of the following is the least accurate regarding his likely condition?

options.A: Conservative management with loop diuretics is curative
options.C: Commonly caused by tuberculosis in endemic regions
options.D: CT scan can assist in visualizing pericardial calcification

questions.explanation: X-ray, and a thickened pericardium on echocardiography is suggestive of constrictive pericarditis . This condition is associated with diastolic dysfunction and signs of right-sided heart failure due to a rigid pericardium restricting heart filling. Diuretics may help reduce symptoms but do not cure constrictive pericarditis; the definitive treatment is pericardiectomy. Investigations: Investigation Purpose/Details Chest X-ray Detects pericardial calcification, a key diagnostic clue. Echocardiography Visualises thickened pericardium and assesses cardiac function. CT scanning Helps in visualising pericardial calcification. Complex echo-Doppler and cardiac catheterisation Used to differentiate constrictive pericarditis from restrictive cardiomyopathy when diagnosis is uncertain. Management: Management Type Treatment Purpose/Details Medical Management Diuretics (e.g., loop diuretics, spironolactone) Helps manage diastolic heart failure by reducing fluid overload. Surgical Management Pericardiectomy Definitive treatment through surgical removal of the diseased pericardium. Significant

On examination, he has elevated jugular venous pressure (JVP), hepatomegaly, and a loud third heart sound. There is also a rise in JVP during inspiration (see image below). Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.A: Heart failure with preserved ejection fraction

questions.explanation: heart sound), Kussmaul’s sign (Paradoxical rise in JVP during inspiration), hepatomegaly , and peripheral oedema , all suggestive of constriction around the heart. Constrictive Pericarditis: Pathophysiology: Progressive thickening, fibrosis, and calcification of the pericardium restrict heart filling. Calcification can extend into the myocardium, impairing myocardial contraction. Restricted ventricular filling leads to elevated atrial pressures, causing: Atrial hypertrophy Atrial dilation Atrial fibrillation (common). Primarily manifests as systemic venous congestion (lung congestion is rare). questions.question: A 25 y/o male is brought to the emergency department after a high-speed car accident. He has a deep laceration on his thigh and is actively bleeding. His vitals are heart rate of 120 bpm, blood pressure of 80/50 mmHg, and he is pale with cold, clammy skin. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management step?

options.D: Apply a tourniquet to the thigh

questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) Start intravenous fluid resuscitation Explanation: The patient is in hypovolemic shock due to significant blood loss, which is indicated by the weak vital signs. Immediate fluid resuscitation is critical to restore circulating blood volume while managing the active bleeding. Hypovolemic and Obstructive Shock: Aspect Hypovolemic Shock Obstructive Shock Definition Critical blood loss leads to inadequate organ perfusion. Obstruction of blood flow, impairing the heart's ability to pump blood. Causes Traumatic injuries (deep lacerations, internal bleeding) from crashes. Injuries like tension pneumothorax, and cardiac tamponade in crashes. Symptoms Dizziness, rapid heartbeat, cold skin, pale lips, nausea, confusion. Rapid heartbeat, difficulty breathing, cold skin, anxiety. Pathophysiology Initial compensation fails, leading to low blood pressure, and multi-organ failure. Physical blockage reduces oxygen delivery to organs. Treatment Volume resuscitation (IV fluids, blood transfusions), control bleeding. Relieve obstruction (needle decompression, pericardiocentesis), and fluid resuscitation. Administer intravenous antibiotics (Option A) : While necessary in trauma cases to prevent infection, it is not the priority in acute shock management. Perform an urgent CT scan (Option B) : Imaging is important for diagnosis but should be deferred until the patient is stabilised. Apply a tourniquet to the thigh (Option D) : This can be used if bleeding is not controlled by direct pressure, but fluid resuscitation is the immediate priority. Reference: www.procaremedcenter.com/delayed-shock-symptoms-after-accident/ www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK513297/

questions.question: A 60 y/o woman presents to the ED with severe shortness of breath and chest tightness. O/E, she is hypotensive with a blood pressure of 85/60 mmHg, has distended neck veins with a jugular venous pressure (JVP) of 12 cm H I O, and her heart sounds are muffled. An echocardiogram shows the following: What is the most appropriate immediate and definitive treatment for this patient?
questions.explanation: echocardiographic evidence of right ventricular collapse—suggests cardiac tamponade. Cardiac tamponade Investigations Treatment Echocardiography : Primary diagnostic tool. The diastolic collapse of the right ventricle. Assesses pericardial effusion (size, location). Normal E/A Ratio: In healthy individuals, the E/A ratio is typically greater than 1, indicating effective ventricular filling. Diastolic Dysfunction: In cardiac tamponade, the E/A ratio can decrease to less than 1, signifying impaired diastolic filling and relaxation. Shows respiratory variations in transvalvular flow velocities. ECG : Shows low QRS voltage due to fluid interference. May present electrical alternans, indicating tamponade. Right Heart Catheterization : Provides haemodynamic data. Reveals elevated and equalized pressures in all cardiac chambers during diastole . Pericardiocentesis: Immediate procedure to drain fluid and relieve pressure on the heart. (Option B) Often guided by echocardiography. Intravenous Saline : Given temporarily while getting ready for the procedure. (Option A ruled out) Catheter Placement : A small catheter may be left in place post-pericardiocentesis for ongoing drainage if fluid reaccumulates. Surgical Drainage (Subxiphoid Pericardiotomy): Indicated for recurrent tamponade, loculated effusions, or ineffective pericardiocentesis. (Option D ruled out) Pericardial Fluid Analysis : Important for identifying the underlying cause of the effusion (e.g., cytology, cultures, PCR for infections). questions.question: Which of the following is a classic finding in cardiac tamponade?
questions.explanation: systolic blood pressure during inspiration (greater than 10 mm Hg). It occurs due to the impaired filling of the heart chambers caused by pericardial fluid compression, limiting cardiac output during inspiration. This phenomenon is commonly observed in cardiac tamponade and serves as a key diagnostic feature in such cases. Cardiac Tamponade Definition A condition where the cardiac chambers are compressed by a tense pericardial effusion, limiting cardiac inflow. Fluid accumulation of as little as 200 ml to upwards of 2L may lead to cardiac tamponade development. Clinical Features Beck's triad Jugular Venous Distension : Due to increased central venous pressure. Prominent x descent and an absent y descent. Hypotension : Resulting from impaired cardiac output. Muffled Heart Sounds : Caused by fluid accumulation in the pericardial space, dampening heart sounds. Other features Pulsus Paradoxus : A drop in systolic BP during inspiration, greater than 10 mm Hg. Causes of Pulsus paradoxus: Lung Conditions: Acute asthma, COPD, tension pneumothorax, pleural effusion, pulmonary embolism. Heart Conditions: Cardiac tamponade, constrictive pericarditis. Low-Pressure Cardiac Tamponade Definition This occurs when lower pericardial pressure leads to tamponade, often in cases of intravascular fluid depletion (e.g., hypovolemia). Features Jugular Venous Distension: Often absent Pulsus Paradoxus: Rare Requires a high degree of suspicion due to the absence of typical signs like jugular venous distension and pulsus paradoxus. S3 heart sound (Option B): An S3 heart sound, also known as a ventricular gallop, is typically associated with heart failure or conditions causing rapid filling of the ventricles, such as dilated cardiomyopathy. It is not a classic finding in cardiac tamponade, which is more characterized by restricted ventricular filling and muffled heart sounds rather than additional heart sounds like S3. Pulsus alternans (Option C): Pulsus alternans refers to alternating strong and weak pulse beats, typically seen in left ventricular dysfunction, not cardiac tamponade. High-pitched systolic murmur (Option D): A high-pitched systolic murmur is usually associated with valvular heart diseases, such as aortic stenosis or mitral regurgitation, not cardiac tamponade Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 1853, 2021, 2022 www.ahajournals.org/doi/full/10.1161/circulationaha.106.634584 www.sciencedirect.com/topics/medicine-and-dentistry/cardiac-tamponade www.webmd.com/heart-disease/what-is-pulsus-paradoxus

questions.question: A 65-year-old man presents to the emergency department with complaints of shortness of breath, fatigue, and mild chest discomfort. On examination, his blood pressure is low, and his heart sounds are faint on auscultation. The physician orders an echocardiogram, which shows the following Based on these findings, which of the following ECG patterns would you most likely expect to see?
questions.explanation: around the heart , with evidence of impaired filling of the right-sided chambers are suggestive of cardiac tamponade, likely due to a large pericardial effusion. Electrical alternans is a classic ECG finding in pericardial effusion , particularly when it leads to cardiac tamponade. It manifests as beat-to-beat variations in the amplitude of the QRS complexes, reflecting the heart's movement within the fluid-filled pericardial space. This finding is indicative of significant fluid accumulation and increased intrapericardial pressure, which impedes the heart's ability to fill properly during diastole. questions.question: A 60 y/o male with acute pericarditis who has not responded to NSAIDs and colchicine is now experiencing frequent recurrences. He does not tolerate glucocorticoids well. What additional treatment can be considered?

options.C: Begin a higher dose of colchicine

questions.explanation: such as azathioprine can be considered. Azathioprine is used for patients with recurrent, refractory pericarditis who have multiple episodes lasting for extended periods. Acute Pericarditis Investigations Treatment Echocardiography : The primary tool for diagnosing pericardial fluid. Significant pericardial effusion can be identified if fluid exceeds 1 cm. CT & MRI : Detect loculated effusions, masses, or inflammation (MRI) Used to confirm pericardial effusion or thickening. MRI also assesses fibrosis and constrictive pericarditis. Conservative Management: Rest and anti-inflammatory drugs for idiopathic pericarditis. Aspirin/NSAIDs : Doses: Aspirin (2-4 g/day) or ibuprofen/indomethacin with gastric protection. Continue for 1-2 weeks, and taper over time. Colchicine : Dose: 0.5 mg daily (<70 kg) or twice daily (>70 kg) for 3 months. Reduces recurrence risk but may cause diarrhoea. Glucocorticoids : Only for NSAID/colchicine-resistant cases, short-term use (2-4 days), then tapered. Prolonged use raises the recurrence risk. Immunosuppressants : Azathioprine or anakinra in cases of frequent recurrence is unresponsive to other treatments. Avoid Anticoagulants : Risk of bleeding into the pericardial cavity, leading to tamponade. Surgical: Pericardial stripping for rare, severe cases with recurrent effusion. Increase the dose of NSAIDs (Option A): NSAIDs are effective for inflammation control in the short term, but increasing the dosage does not provide additional benefit once recurrences occur. Begin a higher dose of colchicine (Option C): Increasing the dose beyond the recommended levels is not advisable, as colchicine has a narrow therapeutic window . Higher doses increase the risk of gastrointestinal side effects, such as diarrhoea, and can be toxic, especially in patients with liver or kidney problems. Stop all medications and monitor (Option D): Stopping all medications without an alternative treatment plan is not appropriate in recurrent pericarditis cases. It can lead to persistent discomfort and potential complications. Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 1853, 2020, 2021
